item.title: Facebook Enlists Fact-Checkers To Probe Disputed Stories
item.description: March 7, 2017 - Facebook has been criticized for providing a platform to fake news stories, especially during the presidential campaign. It is working with independent fact-checkers to examine flagged stories.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 7, 2017 - Facebook has been criticized for providing a platform to fake news stories, especially during the presidential campaign. It is working with independent fact-checkers to examine flagged stories. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/07/518956912/facebook-enlists-fact-checkers-to-probe-disputed-stories

item.title: Energy Savings Can Be Fun, But No Need To Turn Off All The Lights
item.description: March 7, 2017 - From counting steps to hours of sleep, many people are tracking aspects of their lives. Now one company is merging energy saving with the interest in quantifying — making lowering electricity a game.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 7, 2017 - From counting steps to hours of sleep, many people are tracking aspects of their lives. Now one company is merging energy saving with the interest in quantifying — making lowering electricity a game. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/03/07/518175670/energy-savings-can-be-fun-but-no-need-to-turn-off-all-the-lights

item.title: FAQ: On Alleged Wiretaps Of Trump Communications
item.description: March 6, 2017 - President Trump accused his predecessor of monitoring his communications. Here is a rundown of the allegations, federal surveillance powers, and what we do and don't know.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 6, 2017 - President Trump accused his predecessor of monitoring his communications. Here is a rundown of the allegations, federal surveillance powers, and what we do and don't know. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/06/518797121/faq-on-alleged-wire-taps-of-trump-communications

item.title: Smartphone Software Makes It Cheaper To Spy From A Distance
item.description: March 6, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Joseph Cox, a reporter for the tech website, "Motherboard," about how he tracked himself with $170 smartphone spyware that anyone can buy.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 6, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Joseph Cox, a reporter for the tech website, "Motherboard," about how he tracked himself with $170 smartphone spyware that anyone can buy. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/06/518858280/smartphone-software-makes-it-cheaper-to-spy-from-a-distance

item.title: Emojis Begin Cropping Up Outside Of Your Smartphone
item.description:
March 6, 2017 - Emojis — those little cartoon figures used by some people on smartphones — have became popular as design motifs in the real world.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/03/06/518858273/emojis-begin-cropping-up-outside-of-your-smartphone
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: WATCH: Tracking Lightning Strikes, From Space
item.description: March 6, 2017 - NOAA's new weather satellite is carrying the first lightning detector ever parked in orbit over Earth. It has sent back its first images of real-time lightning storms in the Western Hemisphere.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 6, 2017 - NOAA's new weather satellite is carrying the first lightning detector ever parked in orbit over Earth. It has sent back its first images of real-time lightning storms in the Western Hemisphere. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/06/518776626/watch-tracking-lightning-strikes-from-space

item.title: Feeling Lonely? Too Much Time On Social Media May Be Why
item.description: March 6, 2017 - It's not clear whether spending a lot of time on Facebook, Snapchat or Instagram leads to social isolation, or whether the lonely seek solace in social media.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 6, 2017 - It's not clear whether spending a lot of time on Facebook, Snapchat or Instagram leads to social isolation, or whether the lonely seek solace in social media. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/06/518362255/feeling-lonely-too-much-time-on-social-media-may-be-why

item.title: H-1B Visa Debate: Are Foreign Tech Workers Hired Over Americans?
item.description: March 6, 2017 - Many employers say they need H-1B workers because of a talent shortage among U.S. tech companies. But some Americans say the program that allows foreigners to be hired has put them out of work.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 6, 2017 - Many employers say they need H-1B workers because of a talent shortage among U.S. tech companies. But some Americans say the program that allows foreigners to be hired has put them out of work. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/06/518743020/h-1b-visa-debate-are-foreign-tech-workers-hired-over-americans

item.title: S. Korea: North Test-Fires Handful Of 'Unknown Projectiles' Into Japan Waters
item.description: March 5, 2017 - The projectiles were launched Sunday from near North Korea's missile base of Tongchang-ri, says South Korea's military. At least one of the missiles flew about 620 miles.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 5, 2017 - The projectiles were launched Sunday from near North Korea's missile base of Tongchang-ri, says South Korea's military. At least one of the missiles flew about 620 miles. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/05/518695871/s-korea-n-korea-test-fires-handful-of-unknown-projectiles-into-japan-waters

item.title: Does Nintendo's New Console Signal A 'Switch' For The Video Game Market?
item.description: March 5, 2017 - There's hype surrounding Nintendo's first home-to-handheld hybrid console, Switch. Wall Street Journal technology reporter Nathan Olivarez-Giles says this could be a make or break moment for Nintendo.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 5, 2017 - There's hype surrounding Nintendo's first home-to-handheld hybrid console, Switch. Wall Street Journal technology reporter Nathan Olivarez-Giles says this could be a make or break moment for Nintendo. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/05/518663843/does-nintendos-new-console-signal-a-switch-for-the-video-game-market

item.title: As Amazon Moves In, A Local Bookseller Hopes To Thrive With A Personal Touch
item.description: March 4, 2017 - Amazon has opened its latest brick-and-mortar bookstore — the first on the East Coast. But an independent bookseller in the Boston suburb says: "I think that we're going to be OK."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 4, 2017 - Amazon has opened its latest brick-and-mortar bookstore — the first on the East Coast. But an independent bookseller in the Boston suburb says: "I think that we're going to be OK." http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/03/04/517958727/as-amazon-moves-in-a-local-bookseller-hopes-to-thrive-with-a-personal-touch

item.title: How YouTube Is Changing Our Viewing Habits
item.description: March 4, 2017 - People watch 1 billion hours of video every day on YouTube. NPR's Scott Simon talks to Dr. Zeynep Tufekci of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill about YouTube's impact on society.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 4, 2017 - People watch 1 billion hours of video every day on YouTube. NPR's Scott Simon talks to Dr. Zeynep Tufekci of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill about YouTube's impact on society. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/04/518461970/how-youtube-is-changing-our-viewing-habits

item.title: St. Louis Man Accused Of Making Threats Against Jewish Centers, Schools
item.description: March 3, 2017 - The threats were allegedly part of the suspect's cyberstalking campaign against a woman with whom he once had a romantic relationship. Juan Thompson once worked as a reporter at The Intercept.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 3, 2017 - The threats were allegedly part of the suspect's cyberstalking campaign against a woman with whom he once had a romantic relationship. Juan Thompson once worked as a reporter at The Intercept. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/03/518331335/st-louis-man-accused-of-making-threats-against-jewish-centers-schools

item.title: One Big Winner Of Snap's Even Bigger IPO: A School That Raked In Millions
item.description: March 3, 2017 - In 2012, Saint Francis High School put up $15,000 in seed money for the founders of a fledgling Snapchat. By the time the company went public Thursday, the school turned it into a $24 million return.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 3, 2017 - In 2012, Saint Francis High School put up $15,000 in seed money for the founders of a fledgling Snapchat. By the time the company went public Thursday, the school turned it into a $24 million return. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/03/518316013/one-big-winner-of-snaps-even-bigger-ipo-a-school-that-raked-in-millions

item.title: Amazon And The $150 Million Typo
item.description: March 3, 2017 - Amazon said a mistyped command caused part of the company's cloud computing service to go down for hours on Tuesday. The Wall Street Journal reported the outage caused millions of dollars in losses.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 3, 2017 - Amazon said a mistyped command caused part of the company's cloud computing service to go down for hours on Tuesday. The Wall Street Journal reported the outage caused millions of dollars in losses. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/03/518322734/amazon-and-the-150-million-typo
